facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 96 to 98 of 1964 were filed by special leave.

facts.text: Appeals from judgments and orders dated September 22, 1960, and December 6, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 19 of 1958 and 6 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated September 22, 1960, and December 6, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 19 of 1958 and 6 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. On April 10, 1953 the estate of the joint

facts.text: On April 10, 1953, the estate of the joint Hindu family of which the respondent was a member was partitioned.

anchor.surface_text: On April 10, 1953 the estate of the joint Hindu family of which the respondent was a member was partitioned,

facts.text: Respondent was allotted 400 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd. on partition.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent was allotted, besides other properties, 400shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd., and was made liable to pay a business debt

facts.text: Respondent made liable to pay business debt of Rs. 3,91,875/- due by family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: amounting to Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi. On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust

facts.text: On April 14, 1953, respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares allotted to him.

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills which fell of to his share.

facts.text: Deed of trust settled 300 shares numbering 1 to 300 for benefit of creditors and other beneficiaries.

anchor.surface_text: AND WHEREAS for discharge of the debts detailed in the schedule appearing hereafter, the author number as absolute owner of the said shares has decided to settle on trust three hundred shares numbering 1 to 300 both inclusive,

facts.text: Trust declared irrevocable, shares held by trustees to pay off debts in Schedule A first.

anchor.surface_text: hereby declares that the said shares shall from this day be irrevocably held on Trust by the Trustees to be used by them for all or any of the purposes following, that is to say -- To pay off the debts as detailed in Schedule A attached hereto

facts.text: Debts in Schedule A incurred for benefit of Joint Hindu Family, payable by author post-partition.

anchor.surface_text: These debts were incurred for the benefit of the Joint Hindu Family of the author and on disruption of the Joint Hindu Family and partition of properties among its members, made payable by the author.

facts.text: Four trustees appointed including respondent as Chairman for lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: By el. 3 four persons including the respondent were appointed trustees, and the respondent was to hold the office of Chairman of the Trust during his lifetime.

facts.text: Shares to stand in name of Chairman who can vote, operate bank accounts.

anchor.surface_text: In the books of the Company, the shares will stand in the name of the Chairman for the time being, who will have the power to operate the Bank accounts of the Trust, to preside at the meetings, exercise the right of th e vote

facts.text: Trustees can mortgage or pledge shares to pay debts, but not sell except after 10 years if needed.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees shall number be entitled to sell the shares except as provided hereafter but they can mortgage or pledge the same for raising funds as they may feel necessary for paying off the debts of the author, provided ... if the trustees are unable to pay off the debts, out of the income i.e. dividends, bonuses etc. of the shares within a period of ten years they shall be entitled to sell

facts.text: Respondent claimed before Income-tax Officer that dividend on 300 shares is Trust income, he divested ownership.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed before the Income-tax Officer, Eward. Amritsar that the dividend received by the trustees in respect of 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills was the income of the Trust and that he had numberconcern with that income as he had divested himself irrevocably of the ownership of the shares

facts.text: Respondent claimed deduction of Rs. 19,856/- as interest to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand from dividend income.

anchor.surface_text: and that in any event Rs. 19,856/- being the amount due as interest to R. B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand should be allowed as a permissible deduction in companyputing the net income from dividend of the shares.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected claims, held Trust fictitious.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytentions of the respondent, holding that the Trust was a fictitious transaction.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held no irrevocable transfer, s.16(1)(c) proviso applies.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the respondent had number irrevocably transferred the 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills and therefore by virtue of s. 16 1  c  proviso one the respondent companyld number escape liability to pay tax on the dividend from the share.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld lower decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. but without success.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court at Chandigarh at respondent's instance.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal drew up a statement of the case and referred the following questions to the High Court at Chandigarh

facts.text: High Court answered first question in negative: dividend not assessee's income.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question.

facts.text: High Court declined to answer second question on deduction.

anchor.surface_text: and declined to answer the second question. With special leave. the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave. the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Genuineness of the trust is no longer in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Genuineness of the trust is numberlonger  1  53 I.T.R. 195,202. in dispute.

facts.text: Shares to stand in Chairman's name due to s.33 Indian Companies Act 1913 preventing notice of trust on register.

anchor.surface_text: The direction that the shares are to stand in the name of the Chairman for the time being appears to have been necessitated by s. 33 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 which prevented numberice of any trust,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds settlement not revocable under s.16(1)(c) first proviso.

concepts.unlisted_label: Second Proviso to Section 16(1)(c) Income-tax Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Broadens scope of settlement/disposition to include trusts etc.

issues.text: Whether the dividend income of 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills, Private Ltd. transferred by the assessee to S. Raghbir Singh Trust was the income of the assessee liable to tax?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties concede; prior lower court findings on fictitiousness rejected implicitly by proceeding on merits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory requirement under Companies Act explains registration in Chairman's name; does not imply settlor retention of control.

holdings.text: The shares were settled upon trust irrevocably; income arises to trustees, impressed with trust obligations; direction to pay settlor's debts does not provide for retransfer of income/assets or right to reassume power directly/indirectly under first proviso to s.16(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: If by the direction for application of the income for satisfaction of the debts due by the respondent, it could be said in law that there is a provision for retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or a right to reassume directly or indirectly power over the income, the settlement would be deemed revocable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of deed: irrevocable declaration, trustees hold for specified purposes; debt payment benefits settlor indirectly but lacks specific proviso-triggering provision; income applied per trust, not revested.

holdings.text: Settlor obtains benefit from trust consequent upon satisfaction of his liability, but on that account the first proviso to s.16(1)(c) is not attracted.

anchor.surface_text: The settlor it is true obtains benefit from the trust consequent upon satisfaction of his liability, but on that account the first proviso is not attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Benefit alone insufficient; proviso requires explicit provision for retransfer or power reassumption, directly or indirectly.

holdings.text: By the use of 'indirectly' in first proviso to s.16(1)(c), Legislature did not seek to cover cases where settlor discharges own liability under guise of trust.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of counsel for the revenue that by the use of the expression indirectly in the first proviso the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of cl. c cases where the settler was under the guise of a trust seeking to discharge his own liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects purposive expansion; proviso limited to provisions enabling retransfer/power reassumption directly/indirectly; not general anti-avoidance for debt discharge.

holdings.text: Provisos to s.16(1)(c) explanatory: first proviso deems specific settlements revocable for principal clause.

anchor.surface_text: It was observed in a recent judgment of this Court Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa v. Rani Bhuwanesliwari Kuer that By the first proviso, settlements, dispositions or transfers of the character described therein, are deemed revocable for the purpose of the principal clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows own precedent on proviso function.

holdings.text: Trusts to discharge personal obligation (arising from status) do not attract s.16(1)(c), as held in Ramji Keshavji v. CIT and D.R. Shahapure v. CIT.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held in two cases decided by the High Court of Bombay that a person under an obligation arising out of his status may execute a trust to discharge his own obligation without attracting the operation of s.16(1)(c).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous precedents: no retransfer/power provision despite benefit to settlor/family.

anchor.surface_text: Commis- sioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa v. Rani Bhuwanesliwari Kuer 1  that By the first proviso, settlements, dispositions or transfers of the character described therein, are deemed revocable for the purpose of the principal clause.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa v. Rani Bhuwanesliwari Kuer
precedents.cited_proposition: By the first proviso, settlements, dispositions or transfers of the character described therein, are deemed revocable for the purpose of the principal clause. The function of proviso I and proviso 2 is plainly explanatory. Settlements are deemed revocable if containing provision for retransfer or right to reassume power over income or assets.
precedents.cited_holding: The terms of s. 16(1)(c) first proviso are reasonably plain. A settlement or disposition is deemed to be statutorily revocable if there is a provision therein for retransfer of the income or assets or which confers a right to reassume power over the income or assets.

precedents.citation: Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1  under a companysent decree. the assessee executed a deed of trust companyveying certain properties for the benefit of his wife. to the trustees.

precedents.case_name: Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: A person under an obligation arising out of his status may execute a trust to discharge his own obligation without attracting the operation of s. 16(1)(c)
precedents.cited_holding: The income derived from the trust property and payable to the assessee's wife during her lifetime could not be deemed to be the assessee's income, for the direction in the deed did not amount to a provision for retransfer of the income or assets or for reassumption of power directly or indirectly over income or assets within the meaning of the first proviso to s. 16(1)(c).

precedents.citation: D.R. Shahapure v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: D.R. Shahapure v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2  the assessee with the object of making a provision for his wife made an entry in his business books of account crediting Rs. 20,000/-, and endorsed against the entry.

precedents.case_name: D.R. Shahapure v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: A person under an obligation arising out of his status may execute a trust to discharge his own obligation without attracting the operation of s. 16(1)(c)
precedents.cited_holding: The entry was an irrevocable covenant to pay the income accruing on Rs. 20,000/- with a guarantee that it shall be Rs. 600 per annum, and did not attract s. 16(1)(c).
